docs.lead_paragraph: Appealing for support from the "vital center," President Clinton today put forward the broad outlines of his plan to guarantee health care for all Americans, in part by requiring every employer to provide insurance coverage for employees. While Republicans and small-business advocates warned that the plan could result in the loss of millions of jobs, the White House said it intended to ease the burden on employers by recommending that the plan not take full effect for five to seven years.

headline.main: CLINTON OUTLINES HEALTH CARE PLAN PAID BY EMPLOYERS

docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal court today ordered the Warner-Lambert Company to stop manufacturing most new drug products while inspections are carried out to determine whether its plants meet Food and Drug Administration standards. An exception was made for a handful of drugs that are considered medically necessary, which will continue to be produced and shipped.

headline.main: Warner-Lambert to Halt Most Drug Production

docs.lead_paragraph: "HURRY, hurry -- use the new drugs while they still work!" a 19th-century French physician urged his colleagues. He may not have known why faddish drugs work on credulous patients, but the fact that they do has been borne out by scientists studying the power of the placebo to cure. New findings show that the placebo effect -- in which patients given an inactive treatment believe it can cure them -- is most powerful when a trusted physician enthusiastically offers a patient a new therapy. In a study of more than 6,000 patients being given experimental treatments for asthma, duodenal ulcer and herpes, two-thirds improved, at least temporarily, even though rigorous tests later found the treatments medically useless. They were then abandoned.

headline.main: Placebo Effect Is Shown to Be Twice as Powerful as Expected

docs.lead_paragraph: Over strenuous objections by some drug companies, the Federal Government is establishing a program guaranteeing free vaccine for millions of children who are poor or uninsured. Under the program, which Congress created as part of the budget bill and the President signed into law on Tuesday, the Government will buy the vaccine at discount prices from drug manufacturers and distribute it at no charge to doctors who choose to participate. The doctors, in turn, will not charge patients for the vaccine. Though they may charge a fee for administering the vaccine, they cannot turn away a child whose parents are unable to pay.

headline.main: U.S. TO GUARANTEE FREE IMMUNIZATION FOR POOR CHILDREN
